reviews.review_text: Quite a different spin on his usual detective series. Takes you on a slippery & deep study of human actions/reactions while in and around the western glaciers. Opens many skeletons in the closet (or rather the freezer).
Good story, but it seemed to have a lot to do with alcoholism.

Set in 1970s Iceland, when Inspector Erlendur is just starting out as a young traffic cop on nights. But when a drunk, whom he's encountered a few times, is found dead in a pond, Erlendur starts investigating on his own account... And finds a second - and apparently non-related - missing person case might be linked to it...In between, we accompany Erlendur and his colleagues on their patrols; often irrelevant to the main story, these tales of drugs, theft, drink and violence may add to the background, but feel rather like padding.An OK read but nothing very outstanding
I tried this author, it moved a tad slow but enjoyed the read.
Nordic Noir at its best.  I like these kind of police murder mysteries.
This is the prequel to the Erlandur stories. He's working the nightbeat but spends a lot of time investigating two crimes that he cares about but I didn't. Plodding.
I am a big fan of Indridason.  His character Erlendur is my favorite!!
Indridason is always excellent. I recommend any of his books

summary:
In Reykjavik Nights, a stunning prequel to his critically acclaimed Inspector Erlendur series, Arnaldur Indriðason gives his devoted fans a real shock.

Erlendur is a young officer assigned to traffic duties. He is not yet a detective. He works nights. Reykjavík’s nights are full of car crashes, robberies, fights, drinking, and sometimes an unexplained death.

One night a homeless man Erlendur knows is found drowned. Then a young woman on her way home from a club vanishes and both cases go cold.

But Erlendur’s instincts tell him that the fates of these two victims are worth pursuing. He is inexorably drawn into a world where everyone is either in the dark or on the run.
